metadata.title: Winning streaks, randomness, and cognitive bias: Are Man United getting better under Solskjaer? | by Jack Tattersall | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Winning streaks, randomness, and cognitive bias: Are Man United getting better under Solskjaer?

all_paragraphs: Some of my favourite footballing memories involve Manchester United having a terrible time. Dirk Kuyt’s hat-trick in 2011. Luis Suárez tucking in Liverpool’s third at Old Trafford in 2014. Pretty much everything to do with David Moyes. After enduring a pretty torrid 20–30 years, the last few seasons have been considerably kinder to those of us who aren’t so keen on that particular shade of red.

So, yeah, maybe I’m not the most impartial of analysts who could be writing a post like this. I am willing to admit there may be a chance that I’m more likely to pay attention to stats that paint United as a second-rate team with no hope of improving. We’re all human, after all.

Having said that, it does sort of feel like we’ve had our fun by now. We’ve had seven years of — let’s be clear — thoroughly enjoyable schadenfreude, but there is something about it that’s just starting to lose its edge. It’s always great seeing your bitter rivals beaten into second place — but when they keep on being rubbish, it does start to make that rivalry somewhat less bitter. Beating the bad guys is only fun when there’s a chance you might lose. And Pep Guardiola’s team of slick, polite, attractive professionals playing their nice shiny passing football frankly just aren’t villainous enough to properly replace them.

So when The Athletic wrote — ever so tentatively — that we might have to start considering Manchester United as a “good” team after their 2–0 win over Everton in the League Cup, my reaction was one of grudging acceptance. Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s team have won three in a row for only their third time ever under his leadership. They’ve won their last 14 away from home in domestic competition. The football fan in me isn’t actively enjoying this run of form of course — but is at least relishing the thought of having a proper rival again.
But the statistician in me...paused for a moment.

Everyone loves a good fallacy. And one of the classics is the so-called “hot hand” fallacy. First written about by economists in the eighties, the hot hand fallacy is the belief that things that are happening now will continue to happen in the future; that a run of good luck is bound to continue. The term itself comes from basketball, where a player who scored with a number of shots in a row was said to have “hot hands”, and believed to be more likely to score with their next shot than if they weren’t on such a good run. Here’s legendary behavioural economist Richard Thaler briefly explaining it in the film The Big Short.

Although later research has challenged whether this belief is always a fallacy or not, we can still say that a run of good results doesn’t necessarily mean more good results are likely in the future. Humans are generally really bad at understanding randomness and probability. Even when events are randomly distributed, you’ll often get far more streaks of the same result than you might expect. Flip a coin 100 times, for example, and there’s an 85% chance you’ll get ten heads in a row at some point.
So the question is: is United’s recent run of form evidence that they’re actually improving over time? How likely is it that you’d see this set of results if they weren’t getting any better?
This latter statement is our null hypothesis, and it’s what we’re going to test in the rest of this post.

Fortunately, these are fairly trivial statistics to calculate. First up, we need to get some data on all of United’s results under Solksjaer. We can get this from the excellent football-data site, and then do a little manipulation to get the results over time for Manchester United only.
Next up, we can plot all of the league results United have achieved under Solskjaer as a sequence. (Note we’re just focusing on the league here, for simplicity).
We can see a couple of unbeaten runs in there — those sequences of green and grey bars — most notably at the start of Ole’s reign, and in the most recent period.

Next up, let’s conduct a thought experiment. Let’s imagine that United haven’t improved during this period (our null hypothesis). If that were the case, then you would expect that their probability of winning a match, all being equal, would be the same this season as in the previous seasons since Sojskaer’s arrival.

From the start of Ole’s tenure in December 2018 until the beginning of this season, United had won 30 of their 59 games. This means that, on average, their probability of winning a match in this period was 50.8%. This is, of course, a simplification — their actual probability of winning any one of those games would depend on a whole host of factors — but it’ll do to illustrate the point we’re looking at here. This season they’ve won 8 out of 13, or 61.5%.

The question then becomes: if United hadn’t improved, and that probability of winning had remained constant, how likely is it that they would have won those eight games this season? How likely is it that they’d have won four in a row, as they have done recently, and been unbeaten in their last seven?

Let’s start by looking at that overall record. If our null hypothesis is correct, then the team’s games this season could be treated as independent and identically distributed Bernoulli trials, with a probability of success on each trial (p) equal to 0.508.
We can model this using a simple binomial distribution, to calculate the probability of united winning 8 or more of their 13 games this season if they hadn’t made any improvement.
This gives us a probability of around 14%. In other words, it looks unlikely but plausible that United could have won 8 out of 13 games this season without any improvement.

But of course, football isn’t just about wins. We should really look at whether their points per game is significantly greater this season, statistically speaking. For this, we can just run a simple t-test:

The things to look at here are the mean values and the p-value. What we see is that United are achieving 2 points per game this season, compared with around 1.8 in the previous period (since December 2018). But the p-value is 0.627.

This means that, if there were no genuine difference in the underlying distributions generating the points in the two period, there is around a 63% chance of obtaining results as extreme as this. In other words, if United hadn’t actually improved, it’s still entirely plausible, or even likely, that they could’ve achieved the results they have this season.

Sure, p-values and statistical significance are not the be all and end all, and we should retain a healthy degree of scepticism before relying too heavily on them. But what we can say is that the overall set of results this season isn’t by itself entirely convincing evidence of a substantial improvement by United.
Next, let’s look at that run of four consecutive wins. How likely is it that you’d get a run like that this season if the team hadn’t improved?

This gives us a probability of 49.9%. So this means that, without any change in their underlying winning probability, the chances of Ole’s team achieving a four-game winning streak in the first 13 of this season was basically fifty-fifty.
Again, this doesn’t look like convincing evidence of the team getting better.

Finally, we can take a look at that recent unbeaten run of seven games. Again, what we’re asking here is — how likely is it that last season’s United could’ve achieved that? If the answer is “very unlikely”, then that might be evidence that this season’s team is better than before.

There are a couple of different ways we can do this, but we’ll use the same formula as before. Instead of using with win percentage for the p parameter, we’ll use the win or draw percentage. For the December 2018 - September 2020 period, this was 78%.

It turns out this is even less convincing evidence of improvement this season. We find that, even if the team’s average chance of losing a game hadn’t changed, they’d actually have a 74% chance of achieving a seven-game unbeaten run in the first 13 matches of this season.

So, what do we have. We have an unbeaten run that we’re highly confident last season’s United could have achieved. We have a four-game winning streak that they’d have a fifty-fifty chance of managing. And we have an overall points-per-game that hasn’t changed significantly, in statistical terms, and that the 2018–19 team could probably have managed without any underlying improvement.

Of course, this is only part of the picture. I haven’t looked at the quality of opposition that United have played, at which players they’ve had available, at their expected goals or any other underlying performance metrics, at any of the qualitative attributes of their play or the attitude in the dressing room. All of these things are important too. But what we have shown is that, contrary to popular opinion, results alone can be misleading.
And that’s really the key message of this post. A run of good results doesn’t by itself mean a team is suddenly good. A run of bad results doesn’t necessarily mean the manager should be sacked.
And fans of the red half of Merseyside might have to settle for comfortable smugness for a little while longer before we get our pantomime villains back.
